_readme: Use these scenarios to write golden AI summary examples. Each scenario shows the exact data the AI receives.

meta.name: Fintech Startup
meta.description: 91% score, Level 3 - High performer with some gaps

initiatives.title: Operationalize Driver-Based Planning
initiatives.recommendation: Link CRM pipeline stages directly to revenue forecast. Create driver sensitivity dashboard.

initiatives.title: Formalize Strategic Partnership
initiatives.recommendation: Establish Finance review checkpoint for pricing and deal terms. Join product launch committee.

fintech_startup.tonality_instructions:
- Budget Discipline (95%): This is a strength. Validate success briefly. Ask what drives it. Do not dwell — move on.
- Financial Controls (88%): This is a strength. Validate success briefly. Ask what drives it. Do not dwell — move on.
- Performance Monitoring (92%): This is a strength. Validate success briefly. Ask what drives it. Do not dwell — move on.
- Forecasting Agility (85%): This is a strength. Validate success briefly. Ask what drives it. Do not dwell — move on.
- Driver-Based Planning (78%): Foundation exists but gaps remain. Focus on specific friction points. Be constructive, not alarming.
- Scenario Modeling (90%): This is a strength. Validate success briefly. Ask what drives it. Do not dwell — move on.
- Strategic Influence (82%): This is a strength. Validate success briefly. Ask what drives it. Do not dwell — move on.

golden_example.executive_snapshot: PayFlow Technologies' FP&A function operates at a mature Level 3 (Managed) [[level_3]] standard, executing at 91% effectiveness [[score_overall]]. The function has successfully secured its foundational controls, allowing the focus to shift from 'process stability' to 'strategic optimization'.
golden_example.strengths: The organization demonstrates advanced capability in Budget Discipline [[obj_budget_discipline]] and Performance Monitoring [[obj_performance_monitoring]]. By establishing a rigorous framework for planning and variance management, you have created a reliable platform that can now support more complex, driver-based modeling.
golden_example.constraints: No critical governance constraints are currently limiting maturity [[cap_inactive]]. However, the score is capped by Driver-Based Planning [[obj_driver_based_planning]] at 78%. While not a risk factor, this gap likely limits your ability to explain forecast outcomes through operational levers, relying instead on static accounting variances.
golden_example.opportunity_areas:
With Budget Discipline already performing strongly, the analysis points to Driver-Based Planning [[obj_driver_based_planning]] as the highest-value refinement opportunity.

• The Action: Operationalizing driver linkages [[init_driver_based]] tends to strengthen forecast defensibility.
• The Benefit: This connects financial projections directly to the operational metrics that business leaders control.
golden_example.path_forward: The path is one of optimization, not remediation. Because the primary gap (Driver-Based Planning) complements your existing strengths, closing it serves a dual purpose: it hardens the forecast narrative and explicitly positions Finance as a strategic commercial partner [[obj_strategic_influence]].

meta.name: Manufacturing Firm
meta.description: 55% score, Level 2 - Mid-range with clear improvement path

initiatives.title: Establish Rolling Forecast
initiatives.recommendation: Move from annual budget to quarterly reforecast (3+9, 6+6 model). Start with top-line revenue and key cost drivers.

initiatives.title: Build 13-Week Cash Flow Model
initiatives.recommendation: Create direct method cash flow forecast. Track receipts and payments weekly.

initiatives.title: Accelerate Month-End Close
initiatives.recommendation: Implement close checklist with daily status tracking. Target 5 business day close.

manufacturing_firm.tonality_instructions:
- Budget Discipline (70%): Foundation exists but gaps remain. Focus on specific friction points. Be constructive, not alarming.
- Financial Controls (65%): Foundation exists but gaps remain. Focus on specific friction points. Be constructive, not alarming.
- Performance Monitoring (60%): Foundation exists but gaps remain. Focus on specific friction points. Be constructive, not alarming.
- Forecasting Agility (35%): Significant gaps. Be direct but constructive. Focus on risk mitigation. Do not sugarcoat.
- Driver-Based Planning (40%): Foundation exists but gaps remain. Focus on specific friction points. Be constructive, not alarming.
- Scenario Modeling (25%): Significant gaps. Be direct but constructive. Focus on risk mitigation. Do not sugarcoat.
- Strategic Influence (45%): Foundation exists but gaps remain. Focus on specific friction points. Be constructive, not alarming.

golden_example.executive_snapshot: Precision Components Inc. is currently assessed at Level 2 (Defined) [[level_2]] with an execution score of 55% [[score_overall]]. While core reporting processes appear stable and controlled, the data indicates a structural inability to pivot quickly, limiting the function's forward-looking agility.
golden_example.strengths: You demonstrate a secure foundation in Budget Discipline [[obj_budget_discipline]] and Financial Controls [[obj_financial_controls]]. The organization has effectively locked down cost management and approval frameworks—a necessary prerequisite for the advanced planning capabilities you are aiming to build.
golden_example.constraints: Maturity is strictly limited by Forecasting Agility [[obj_forecasting_agility]] [[cap_active]]. Specifically, the absence of a Rolling Forecast [[fpa_l2_q10]] and Cash Flow Visibility [[fpa_l2_q07]] creates a 'blind spot' in risk management. Until addressed, annual budget processes will likely act as a ceiling on maturity, regardless of improvements elsewhere.
golden_example.opportunity_areas:
There is a divergence between intent and capability. Forecasting Agility [[obj_forecasting_agility]] is marked as a top priority, yet it scores 35%—the largest gap in the assessment.

• Recommendation: Prioritize establishing a Rolling Forecast [[init_forecast]].
• Why: This shifts the cadence from 'event-based' to 'continuous,' directly addressing the agility gap.
golden_example.path_forward: Sequence is critical here. Addressing the Rolling Forecast [[init_forecast]] first establishes the necessary muscle memory for modern planning. Once that cadence is active, adding Cash Flow Visibility [[init_cash]] becomes a natural extension of the new process, rather than a separate, overwhelming initiative.

meta.name: Critical L1 Miss
meta.description: 86% score but capped at Level 1 due to critical failures

capped_by_titles: Does the company produce an approved annual budget before the fiscal year begins?
Does the budget include a full P&L down to Net Income?

initiatives.title: Implement Annual Budget Cycle
initiatives.recommendation: Establish a formal budget calendar working backwards 3-4 months. Secure explicit leadership sponsorship to enforce deadlines.

initiatives.title: Extend Budget to Full P&L
initiatives.recommendation: Add interest expense, tax provision, and below-the-line items to budget template.

critical_risks.title: Does the company produce an approved annual budget before the fiscal year begins?
Does the budget include a full P&L down to Net Income?

critical_l1_miss.tonality_instructions:
- Budget Discipline (60%): CRITICAL GAP EXISTS. Be direct about risk. Do not minimize or soften. State consequences clearly.
- Financial Controls (90%): This is a strength. Validate success briefly. Ask what drives it. Do not dwell — move on.
- Performance Monitoring (95%): This is a strength. Validate success briefly. Ask what drives it. Do not dwell — move on.
- Forecasting Agility (88%): This is a strength. Validate success briefly. Ask what drives it. Do not dwell — move on.
- Driver-Based Planning (85%): This is a strength. Validate success briefly. Ask what drives it. Do not dwell — move on.
- Scenario Modeling (80%): This is a strength. Validate success briefly. Ask what drives it. Do not dwell — move on.
- Strategic Influence (75%): Foundation exists but gaps remain. Focus on specific friction points. Be constructive, not alarming.

golden_example.executive_snapshot: GrowthMode SaaS displays a unique profile: high operational execution (86%) [[score_overall]] constrained by specific foundational blockers that keep the maturity assessment at Level 1 (Emerging) [[level_1]]. The function is performing at a high level, but lacks the specific governance structures required for recognized maturity.
golden_example.strengths: The organization demonstrates sophisticated capabilities in Performance Monitoring [[obj_performance_monitoring]] and Forecasting Agility [[obj_forecasting_agility]]. You have effectively built advanced analytical muscle, often outperforming peers in analysis speed and depth.
golden_example.constraints: Despite these strengths, the maturity score hits a 'glass ceiling' due to Budget Discipline [[obj_budget_discipline]] [[cap_active]]. Specifically, the absence of an Approved Annual Budget [[fpa_l1_q01]] (prior to FY start) and an Incomplete P&L structure [[fpa_l1_q02]] act as critical vetoes. Advanced analytics cannot compensate for these missing governance pillars.
golden_example.opportunity_areas:
Budget Discipline [[obj_budget_discipline]] is the singular barrier to advancement.

• The Gap: Missing formal budget approval and P&L completeness.
• The Fix: These are not incremental improvements but structural requirements. Implementing a formal budget calendar [[init_budget_cycle]] is the non-negotiable next step.
golden_example.path_forward: There is a single unlock required. You have essentially built a 'Level 3 engine on a Level 1 chassis.' By addressing the Annual Budget Cycle [[fpa_l1_q01]] and P&L Structure [[fpa_l1_q02]], you remove the artificial ceiling, likely allowing the maturity score to immediately reflect your actual operational capability.

meta.name: SaaS Company
meta.description: 43% score, Level 1 - Significant gaps, remediation focus

initiatives.title: Build Forecasting Infrastructure
initiatives.recommendation: Implement 13-week cash flow and monthly P&L reforecast. Critical for fundraising credibility.

initiatives.title: Develop Scenario Modeling Capability
initiatives.recommendation: Build Base/Bull/Bear scenarios for investor conversations. Show burn rate sensitivities.

initiatives.title: Establish Management Reporting
initiatives.recommendation: Create standard monthly pack: Executive summary, P&L, key SaaS metrics (MRR, churn, CAC).

saas_company.tonality_instructions:
- Budget Discipline (50%): Foundation exists but gaps remain. Focus on specific friction points. Be constructive, not alarming.
- Financial Controls (55%): Foundation exists but gaps remain. Focus on specific friction points. Be constructive, not alarming.
- Performance Monitoring (40%): Foundation exists but gaps remain. Focus on specific friction points. Be constructive, not alarming.
- Forecasting Agility (25%): Significant gaps. Be direct but constructive. Focus on risk mitigation. Do not sugarcoat.
- Driver-Based Planning (30%): Significant gaps. Be direct but constructive. Focus on risk mitigation. Do not sugarcoat.
- Scenario Modeling (20%): Significant gaps. Be direct but constructive. Focus on risk mitigation. Do not sugarcoat.
- Strategic Influence (35%): Significant gaps. Be direct but constructive. Focus on risk mitigation. Do not sugarcoat.

golden_example.executive_snapshot: CloudMetrics Pro is assessed at Level 1 (Emerging) [[level_1]] with an execution score of 43% [[score_overall]]. This indicates that while basic transactional processes are functioning, the organization currently lacks the structural mechanisms required for forward-looking financial steering.
golden_example.strengths: The organization shows developing capability in Financial Controls [[obj_financial_controls]]. By establishing foundational approval workflows and month-end rigor, you have created a stable starting point from which to address the broader planning gaps.
golden_example.constraints: Maturity is actively capped by gaps in Forecasting Agility [[obj_forecasting_agility]] and Scenario Modeling [[obj_scenario_modeling]] [[cap_active]]. The specific absence of Cash Flow Visibility [[fpa_l2_q07]] implies a risk profile where the business may be reacting to liquidity changes rather than anticipating them.
golden_example.opportunity_areas:
Your priorities (Forecasting Agility and Scenario Modeling) align directly with your most critical gaps.

• Primary Action: Establish a 13-week cash flow model [[init_forecast_infra]]. This provides immediate visibility for operational decision-making.
• Secondary Action: Build basic Scenario capability [[init_scenario]] (Base/Bull/Bear) to improve stakeholder communication during volatility.
golden_example.path_forward: The data suggests a 'Dual Mandate.' Because your critical constraints lie exactly within your top priority areas [[obj_forecasting_agility]] [[obj_scenario_modeling]], your roadmap is clear: Fix Cash Flow to protect the downside, and build Scenario Models to capture the upside. This simultaneously resolves risk and advances strategy.
